div.head: ¶To my worthy and honoured friend, Maister VValter Aston.
div.p: SIR, though without suspition of flatterie I might in more ample and freer tearmes, intymate my affection vnto you, yet hauing so sensible a tast of your generous and noble disposition, which without this habit of ceremony can estimate my loue: I will rather affect breuitie, though it shoulde seeme my fault, then by my tedious complement, to trouble mine owne opinion setled in your iudgement and discretion. I make you the Patron of this Epistle of the Black-Prince, which I pray you accept, till more easier howers may offer vp from me some thing more worthy of your view, and my trauell.
